review_title: Job Coach supporting ID/DD Adults in the community
pros: The part i loved about this job was the flexibility and how easy it was to branch out and learn new skills.
cons: it's a nonprofit so they seem to struggle maintaining modern technology as well as encourage newer ideas. It can be a challenge to implement a new process that is beneficial to staff AND clients.

pros: Alessandra was my manager and while I hope she was able to retire by now, she is one of the coolest, most loving, intelligent, compassionate, and beautiful people I have ever had the honor of meeting. I’m positive that every kind of reprimand/negative interactions I had with her were based on external pressure placed on her by her higher up. One job placement I coached at was so awesome and with the best client that I became friends with many employees there that I still keep in touch with today.
cons: - non inclusive. They clearly valued employees who were white and neuro typical. Everyone I worked with was white and I got reprimanded on my appearance and personality often. I have ADHD and was not on medication and I was told multiple times that my overtly friendly and personable personality was not professional and needed to change. My hairstyle and style was pretty butch back then which was also viewed as unprofessional. I was the only one on my level that had a bachelors degree, POC, and bi-cultural yet my appearance and personality limited me from any form of advancement. I left when it was clear there was no room for advancement (when new hires or newly hired kept getting offered job developer positions) and when I worked at a different company (even after taking a year off from the field), I killed it! MCC actually gave me a chance and of course I did well because I was qualified and way past ready for it! -not focused on client reaching self sufficiency. Clients would be placed in jobs where the employer expected to get 2 employees for the price of one. Clients who could not be left alone in retail environments due to kleptomania would get jobs in retail stores. The company got paid for the job coaching but the second one wasn’t available or funding from DHS ended, the client would get fired for stealing. Profits are essential for business and must be prioritized, but not when it sets a client up for failure or a criminal record. They are the biggest IDD service and had labor workshops similar to prison ones where they get paid cents per piece (assembly) so their unethical practices seemed like overkill. Low pay, of course! Education is not valued.

pros:
- Community outreach and support
- Caring & dedicated staff. Just plain wonderful, chill people to work with. HANDS DOWN the best company/department I've ever worked with. 
- Non-profit with a culture of people-focused policies & works 
- Employer pays 100% of health insurance (without buy ups). 
- Great management & very accommodating to employee needs for FMLA, ADA, etc.
cons:
- It's a non-profit, so pay could be better. Budgets are largely based on State/Fed funding. (Social services are chronically underfunded) 
- Given the above, understaffing, particularly at the direct-care level is a problem. The folks we have are awesome, but deserve far better pay (especially for how hard they work and how difficult/emotionally draining it can be). 
- Some systems/tech are a bit awkward or even archaic. Again, non-profit = tight budgets and many of the government systems we need to work with are even worse when it comes to web portals & report systems.

review_title: High stress, low pay, no advancement
job_title: Life Enrichment Specialist I in Eugene, OR
pros:
I worked for Albertina Kerr for over 9 years. The only consistently good thing about working there was the amount of paid time off which started at two weeks a year and increased an additional week each year you had worked there up to a maximum total of six weeks paid time off each year.

There are almost always opportunities for overtime. 

Paid CPR and First Aid training.

No out of pocket costs for employee's medical, dental and vision insurance. Coverage for family members was available, but unaffordable (it would cost >50% of a full time employee's salary to cover a family of four).

One meal provided per shift.

Some of your coworkers will be absolutely great, but they generally move on to better jobs relatively quickly.

Good job security. It takes a lot to get fired.
cons:
It takes A LOT to get fired. Some staff do almost literally no work and continue to be employed and paid the same as the rest of the staff that has to pick up their slack. Essentially to get fired you have to no-call no-show three days in a short period of time. If you're working and the person that is supposed to come in never shows up, you are stuck there until somebody can be found to come in and relieve you. And the person that didn't show up can come back in the next day with basically no consequences.

On night shift some people would sleep for almost the entire shift, doing no work, wake up just in time to do a bare minimum before the morning shift arrives and never see any consequences beyond maybe a verbal warning.

High turnover among staff means you are training new people how to do the job several times a year and the better they are at the job, the more likely they will be to leave in a short amount of time.

Mandatory monthly staff meetings were completely pointless >75% of the time and produced nothing of value. Meetings were scheduled according to upper management's preferences with little consideration given to staff members schedules. For example scheduling mandatory meetings at 1pm and expecting all staff including those working overnight to be in attendance. 

Sometimes difficult to get ahold of on-call managers, especially on weekends.

Systematic understaffed, which only got worse the longer I worked there.

Raises were few, far between, and didn't keep up with inflation. When I finally left, I was making less money, adjusted for inflation, than when I had started.

Depending on the shift you worked you would either be insanely busy the entire time, or incredibly bored from lack of work to do.

Less than a year after I quit, they closed all Lane County locations.
